COMMENTARY “MARCELINE – AFTER EIGHT YEARS of a successful engagement at the NEW YORK HIPPODROME Sailed (Nov. 15) on the Olympic to fulfil a six months’ engagement in London[.] RETURNING TO AMERICA (September, 1914) with a contract for 32 weeks” Variety, November 17th, 1914, p. 32

The film was available to the public for at least two weeks. It was being shown at the Bijou Theatre as of March 15th whilst at the New York Hippodrome it was running at least as late as March 24th. See “Amusements” The Saratogian, March 15th, 1915, p. 8 and “Hippodrome” Oswego Daily Times, March 24th, 1915, p. 3

The Library of Congress published, in September 2013, a ground breaking analysis of the surviving filmic record from the silent era. That study, by historian and archivist David Pierce, reported that 14% of films from that era survive in their original form, 11% survive in a non-domestic or inferior form, and a further 5% survive as incomplete fragments. According to that study, seventy percent are now completely lost. This high rate of loss has left a significant hole in the cultural understanding of the medium, depriving hundreds of performers, artists, writers, and creators the opportunity to be remembered and appreciated, had their body of work survived to the modern era. See David Pierce The Survival of Silent Feature Films: 1912-1929 (Washington: Council on the Library and Information Resources and the Library of Congress, 2013), pp. 1-15

The materials drawn upon for this reconstruction are as follows: a photo essay which contains five images from Mishaps of Marceline interspersed with images from several other films – these are the only known visual record of that film to survive; and a plot summary which describes, in a reasonable amount of detail, the narrative of the film. There is also an advert for the film appearing in that same issue, though it contains no unique information. See Reel Life, January 23rd, 1915, p. 21, Reel Life, February 13th, 1915, p. 22, Reel Life, February 27th, 1915, pp. 10, 12, 15, 37
